text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MATERIAL CHANGES

Added IRM 4.60.6.1, Program Scope and Objectives, in accordance with the requirements described in IRM 1.11.2, Internal Management Documents System, IRM Process, and renumbered subsequent subsections accordingly.
Revised the referral process to incorporate use of the Industry Case Issue Selection & Collaboration Process (IC ISCP) for Industry Cases per Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) effective 03-12-18.
LB&I, SB/SE and TE/GE personnel
Director, Cross Border Activities (CBA) Large Business and International Division
Table of Contents
Referral Criteria and Procedures 4.60.6 page
Purpose: This IRM provides guidance and technical information on interna- tional referral criteria and procedures.
Program Goals: Ensure that tax returns with certain international features are appropriately referred to, and considered by, the CBA personnel.
LB&I and SB/SE personnel are responsible for following the guidance contained in this IRM section.

Referral Criteria and Procedures 4.60.6

) In the normal course of examining tax returns, examiners may require the sistance of a CBA representative. A request for international assistance either a formal request for the assignment of a CBA representative to the or an informal request that simply seeks a response to a speciﬁc question. either case, the Specialist Referral System (SRS) will be used to request national assistance. The SRS is on the IRS intranet at: All returns meeting the mandatory referral criteria in IRM
# will be ferred using SRS. (

) SRS facilitates communication of the acceptance or rejection of referrals enables management tracking. A key beneﬁt of SRS is that it eliminates dancy in generating the multiple referrals typically required on a case. (
) The SRS is a routing system for specialists’ referrals. (
) Referral recipient access to the SRS requires an approved Form
) Referral recipients may designate temporary access to review referrals for periods when they will be away or otherwise unable to review referrals. IRM

, System Maintenance, for contact information. Conﬁrmation of the warding of a referral is sent by e-mail to both the requestor and the manager. (

If an LB&I Image Network (LIN) link is not provided, formal requests for the assignment of a CBA representative require the requestor to mail or e-mail copies of portions of the returns to the IRR or CBA representative. Referring are encouraged to include additional information that will assist the IRR in evaluating whether to assign a CBA representative to the examination. (

4.60 International Procedures

for making the referral will also be required from the requestor. where supporting documentation is not required include: formal referrals on LCC cases and requests for informal assistance. The IRR may accept the referral by assigning a CBA representative to the case, assigning a CBA sentative to assist on a consultation basis, transferring the referral to the excess inventory pool, or rejecting the referral. Upon assignment, a CBA sentative will receive e-mail notiﬁcation. Additionally, the requestor and the requestor’s manager will receive e-mail notiﬁcation of the IRR’s action. The CBA representative may then access the SRS and view the referral. (

) When another year (subsequent or prior) or a related return with features requiring a referral is added to the examination, a new referral is needed to add the additional year, or taxpayer to the referral. (

) Supporting documentation, such as return information and other relevant taxpayer information, assists the IRR in evaluating a referral. Although generally required, an exception for LCC cases exists under the premise those types of cases typically have extensive documentation and the timing the engagement is frequently planned well in advance so that the of a referral is simply a formality. In LCC engagements where this is not the case, the IRR should contact the ﬁrst level team manager of the referring agent and make arrangements to assess the audit potential of the referred case. (
) The IRR will review the tax return to evaluate international examination potential and whether a CBA representative should be assigned to the nation except as discussed in (
) above. In most situations, this will be accomplished using the LIN link that should be included in the SRS no LIN link is available, copies of the following return pages should be sent the IRR:

for making the referral will also be required from the requestor. Circumstances where supporting documentation is not required include: formal referrals on LCC cases and requests for informal assistance. The IRR may accept the referral by assigning a CBA representative to the case, assigning a CBA repre- sentative to assist on a consultation basis, transferring the referral to the excess inventory pool, or rejecting the referral. Upon assignment, a CBA sentative will receive e-mail notiﬁcation. Additionally, the requestor and the requestor’s manager will receive e-mail notiﬁcation of the IRR’s action. The CBA representative may then access the SRS and view the referral.

Limited detailed information is required from the requestor. An IRR receives the Assistance question via e-mail. This ends the SRS’s involvement in the informal assis- tance request.

Criteria and Procedures

) The IRR reviews the question and assigns it to a CBA representative by for- warding the e-mail. The CBA representative assigned to an informal request has the option of responding by phone or e-mail. (

) Each specialty is required to maintain the routing logic on the SRS. The analyst that maintains the IRR list is responsible for and has administrative access to the routing logic within SRS. All IRR changes shall be to the CBA analyst who maintains that listing. (

) A team manager can edit and delete team members. Territory managers change or delete managers in their territory. For temporary absences, a manager can assign an acting manager. To access the edit menu from the SRS home page, click on “Managers” and select “Edit Specialist Information”. (

) The SRS will not properly route referrals or track activity when a personnel vacancy occurs. There must always be valid routing paths in place. When a vacancy occurs, someone must be designated the responsibility to assign referrals to CBA representative. Similarly, a vacancy at the team or territory level will impair the SRS’ managerial reporting function. Information about changes that cannot be handled by the team or territory manager must be communicated to the CBA analyst with administrative access over SRS. (

) The following actions require changes to SRS routing: a. New team manager enters the program b. Current team manager leaves the program c. Change in acting team managers d. Change in territory managers (

) A CBA representative examining a foreign controlled return will generally only on international issues. If material domestic issues are identiﬁed during the examination, a geographic practice area agent may be assigned to the amination as a team member, or the CBA representative may examine the domestic issue. The CBA representative maintains administrative control of return. (

) The CBA representative charged with the return will assume all examination and case control responsibilities, including, but not limited to: a. Maintaining timely AIMS and IMS updates b. Following all examination procedures and directives pursuant to IRM structions c. Preparing all relevant examination reports pursuant to IRM instructions d. Preparing all relevant closing documents pursuant to IRM instructions (
) The CBA representative charged with the return is responsible for statute controls and securing timely extensions of statutes when warranted. (
) The Commissioner, LB&I and NTEU signed a Letter of Understanding (LOU) on September

, that in part, stipulates: “The CBA representative will responsible for all elements of case control and statute control that are contained in the Internal Revenue Agent Standard Position Description and detailed in IRM
, Examination Process - Assessment Statute of tions Controls.”

International (

) The following offices under the authority of the Commissioner, LB&I - who is the delegated United States Competent Authority for tax matters - rely on expertise of LB&I and SB/SE examiners for assistance with their programs: a. Exchange of Information (EOI) program b. Joint International Taskforce on Shared Intelligence and Collaboration (JITSIC) c. Treaty Assistance and Interpretation Team (TAIT), and d. Advance Pricing and Mutual Agreement (APMA) program These offices are collectively referred to as the “requesting office.” The tance provided by the LB&I and SB/SE personnel to the requesting office is referred to as “ﬁeld services.” (

) The EOI program and JITSIC are administered by EOI and JITSIC analysts based primarily in Washington, DC. At times, these offices request the assis- tance of LB&I or SB/SE personnel in order to fulﬁll foreign-initiated speciﬁc requests for exchange of information made pursuant to international agreements (such as income tax treaties and Tax Information Exchange ments). These offices forward such requests for assistance to LB&I IRRs requests involving large case entities and/or complex international issues) or SB/SE Examination Area Directors (for requests involving individuals and SB/SE entities). The IRRs and Examination Area Directors assign the to examination offices within their respective business divisions. LB&I and SB/SE examination offices assigned to these assistance requests will strive conclude all requested ﬁeld work within

days of receipt in the groups. assigned LB&I or SB/SE personnel will route the results back to the EOI or JITSIC analyst. These procedures are in accordance with the Memo- randum of Understanding between LB&I and SB/SE regarding the of Speciﬁc Requests for Exchange of Information signed in September
More detailed procedures for processing foreign-initiated speciﬁc requests exchange of information may be found in IRM
, Exchange of (

) Any request from the Treaty Assistance and Interpretation Team (TAIT) involving taxpayers and/or returns that meet the following criteria will be forwarded directly to the Director, WIIC, LB&I: a. Individual taxpayer with a foreign address b. Individual taxpayer with an APO or FPO address c. Form
, Foreign Earned Income, is attached to the tax return d. Form
-F, U.S. Income Tax Return of Foreign Corporations ($
Million and under), or e. Form
-NR, U.S. Non-Resident Alien Income Tax Return (

) For a request in which LB&I assistance is required, the requesting office will use the listing of LB&I IRRs to identify who should receive the request. To access the IRR Listing, go to the International Resource and Application Toolbox: https://organization.ds.irsnet.gov/sites/LBIINTL/Dci/IBChq/Toolbox/ Sit
ages/Toolbox.aspx, scroll down to “International Referral Recipient” and click on the referenced link to open the spreadsheet. (

) The LB&I IRR or SB/SE Examination Area Director will maintain a log of all requests received, noting the date of the request, the accountable LB&I or SB/SE examination action office, and the date forwarded to the accountable office.
4.60 International Procedures
Criteria and Procedures

) For a request to LB&I, the IRR will forward the request for ﬁeld services to accountable office (i.e. the appropriate LB&I examination action office team manager) within ﬁve business days of receipt. a. The identiﬁcation of the appropriate team manager will be established local agreement among all of the international teams servicing a lar geographic area with the concurrence of the respective territory managers and practice area directors. b. The IRR should exercise reasonable diligence in meeting the ﬁve-day requirement. (

) Upon receipt of a request for ﬁeld services, the team manager of the able LB&I or SB/SE office will notify the requesting office that the request been received and provide the name of the examiner assigned. This cation should occur as soon as possible, but in no event later than ﬁve business days from the date the request is received by the team manager. an LB&I accountable office, the team manager will also notify their territory manager and/or practice area director in accordance with procedures estab- lished by each practice area. (

) If a request to LB&I is sent by a requesting office to an IRR in error (e.g. incorrect geographical area or practice area), the IRR will, as soon as practi- cable, establish communication with the requesting office and forward the request to the appropriate IRR. (
) If a request to LB&I is sent by an IRR to an LB&I team manager in error not in accordance with the local agreement in paragraph (

) above), the manager will, as soon as practicable, establish communication with the IRR and forward the request to the appropriate recipient. The IRR will record in their log the date the request was sent to the correct accountable office. (

) The requesting office will transmit a request for LB&I ﬁeld services to the in a manner appropriate for the nature of the request. For example, the program prefers to speak to the CBA representative assigned to the request services prior to shipping voluminous documents and data. Requests for services may be submitted in two forms: a. Notice b. Detailed request (

) Notices may be transmitted by phone, fax, e-mail, or regular mail, and will contain the following: • Name and address of the taxpayer • Nature of request • Suspense date • Point of contact in the requesting office Taxpayer information, which includes names and addresses, can be ted by e-mail only in an encrypted attachment. (
) Detailed requests are mailed to the IRR and must contain all of the needed by the accountable office to take the proper action. (

) The requesting office will set a suspense date to reﬂect the period of time within which the requesting office would like the ﬁeld service completed. The suspense date does not apply to APMA teams, but does apply to the review Internal Revenue Manual

) The team manager of the accountable office should inform the requesting office when the examiner has completed the request. Delivery of the report and/or provision of requested documents should be arranged on a case- by-case basis.
